It also outlines the requirements for recording all ICT-related incidents and significant cyber threats, establishing appropriate procedures and processes to ensure a consistent and integrated monitoring, handling and follow-up of ICT-related incidents, and identifying root causes, documenting them and addressing them to prevent the occurrence of such incidents.

This paragraph outlines the process for accepting, documenting, evaluating, prioritizing, and approving changes to IT systems in an orderly way, and implementing them in a coordinated and secure manner. The paragraph also specifies the steps to securely implement changes to live operations, including risk analysis, testing, data backups, reversal plans, and alternative recovery options. Additionally, the paragraph acknowledges that different process rules and checks can be defined for low-risk configuration changes and parameter settings.

The paragraph from DORA that is most closely related to the BAIT article is Article 12, which states that financial entities shall develop and document backup policies and procedures specifying the scope of the data that is subject to the backup and the minimum frequency of the backup, based on the criticality of information or the confidentiality level of the data. This paragraph outlines the requirements for data backup procedures, including the availability, readability, and timeliness of customer and business data as well as the IT systems required to process them. The procedures for recovery and safeguarding the readability of data shall be tested regularly, at least once a year, as part of a sample as well as on an event-driven basis. The requirements for measures for safeguarding data availability, readability, and timeliness as well as for the tests to be performed stem from related risk analyses. With regard to the locations for the storage of data backups, one or multiple additional locations may be required.

Paragraph 8 of DORA is most closely related to the BAIT article: 9.1. IT services encompass all forms of IT procurement; in particular, this includes the provision of IT systems, projects/computer-aided construction projects or staff. Outsourcing of IT services shall meet the requirements pursuant to AT 9 of MaRisk. This shall also apply to the outsourcing of IT services which are provided to the institution by a services firm via a network (e.g. processing, storage, platforms or software) and which are supplied, used and invoiced dynamically and tailored to requirements via defined technical interfaces and protocols (cloud services). The institution shall still comply with the general requirements relating to a proper business organisation pursuant to section 25a (1) of the Banking Act in the case of other external procurement of IT services (see AT 9 number 1 – Explanations – of MaRisk). For each software procurement, the associated risks shall be appropriately assessed (see AT 7.2 number 4 sentence 2 of MaRisk).

Paragraph 8 of DORA states that financial entities shall identify, classify and document all ICT support functions, roles and responsibilities, the information assets and ICT assets supporting those functions, and their roles and dependencies in relation to ICT risk. This includes software procurement, which is specifically mentioned in the BAIT article. The associated risks of software procurement shall be appropriately assessed, as required by MaRisk.

The paragraph that is most closely related to the BAIT article is paragraph 9.4 of DORA. This paragraph states that the contractual arrangements shall take appropriate account of the measures derived from the risk assessment relating to other external procurement of IT services.   The paragraph from DORA that is most closely related to the BAIT article 10.1 is Article 11. This article outlines the requirements for financial entities to establish a comprehensive ICT business continuity policy, which includes the development of backup policies and procedures, restoration and recovery procedures and methods, and the maintenance of redundant ICT capacities. The article also requires financial entities to establish a crisis management function and to keep readily accessible records of activities before and during disruption events. The article emphasizes the importance of testing the backup procedures and restoration and recovery procedures and methods on a periodic basis to ensure their effectiveness. The article also requires financial entities to demonstrate the effectiveness and appropriateness of their contingency plan at least once a year and on an event-driven basis for all relevant scenarios.

The paragraph from DORA that is most closely related to the BAIT article is Article 11, which states that financial entities shall put in place a comprehensive ICT business continuity policy, which may be adapted as a specific policy, forming an integral part of the overall business continuity policy of the financial entity. This policy shall include, among other things, IT contingency plans for IT systems that support time-critical activities and processes, as well as the parameters defined for these, and take account of dependencies in order to restore time-critical activities and processes. The parameters include recovery time objective (RTO), recovery point objective (RPO), and emergency operation configuration. The dependencies include dependencies of upstream and downstream business processes and the IT systems deployed by the institution and (IT) service providers, dependencies in the recovery prioritisation of IT processes and systems, necessary resources for ensuring (limited) continuation of business processes, and dependencies on external factors (lawmakers, shareholders, public, etc.).

  The paragraph that is most closely related to the BAIT article is paragraph 12.1. This paragraph adds requirements for the effective implementation of special measures to achieve the critical infrastructure protection (CIP) objective to the Supervisory Requirements for IT in Financial Institutions. The CIP objective is defined as maintaining the society’s security of supply for critical services, such as cash supply, card-based payment transactions, conventional payment transactions, and the clearing and settlement of securities and derivatives transactions. CI operators and their IT service providers are required to describe and effectively implement appropriate measures for critical services to reduce the risks to the secure operation of critical infrastructure to a level appropriate for the CIP objective. They must align themselves with relevant standards and consider high availability concepts, and use state-of-the-art technology. Companies can choose to use this chapter to provide verification under section 8a (3) of the Act on the Federal Office for Information Security (BSI Act) within the context of an audit of the annual financial statements, which requires that all information technology systems, components, and processes that are part of the critical infrastructure are covered by the audit in full. Alternatively, CI operators can adopt a company-specific approach or create an industry-specific security standard under section 8a (2) of the BSI Act.

This paragraph states that financial entities shall implement ICT business continuity policy and disaster recovery plans through appropriate and documentable arrangements, plans, procedures and mechanisms aiming to ensure the continuity of critical or important functions, quickly and effectively respond to and resolve ICT-related incidents, activate, without delay, dedicated plans that enable containment measures, processes and technologies suited to each type of ICT-related incident and prevent further damage, estimate preliminary impacts, damages and losses, set out communication and crisis management actions that ensure that updat ed information is transmitted to all relevant internal and external stakeholders in accordance with Article 14, and report to the competent authorities in accordance with Article 19. This paragraph also states that financial entities shall put in place, maintain and periodically test appropriate ICT business continuity plans, notably with regard to critical or important functions outsourced or contracted through arrangements with ICT third-party service providers. This paragraph takes into account the CIP objective and the emergency preparedness planning requirements mentioned in the BAIT article 12.4.
